title-group.article-title: Fatigue equation considerations for the American Society of Civil Engineers pre-standard for load and resistance factor design of pultruded fiber-reinforced polymer structures

contrib-group.aff: West Virginia University, Constructed Facilities Center, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, USA

author-notes.corresp: David B Dittenber, West Virginia University, 395 Evansdale Drive, Engineering Science Building, Room 653, Morgantown, WV 26506, USA. Email: ddittenb@mix.wvu.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A recently completed pre-standard for load and resistance factor design of pultruded fiber-reinforced polymer structures includes an S-N fatigue life prediction model for the design of components, which will experience cyclic loading. The prediction is independent of material and geometric properties and is shown to be overly conservative when applied to experimental data. A different model, developed at the Constructed Facilities Center at West Virginia University, is combined with the pre-standard model in order to incorporate material and geometric properties and improve life prediction accuracy from an over-prediction of 50× cycles to failure to only 5×.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The selection and scale of applications for fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) composites in the field of civil engineering have been increasing in recent years. This is largely due to the increased recognition of FRPs being attractive alternatives to conventional construction materials due to higher strength and stiffness with reference to specific gravity, better resistance to corrosion, fire, acids, and natural hazardous environments, longer service life, lower life-cycle costs, as well as higher fatigue resistance and impact energy absorption capacity. Their cost can be very competitive when long-term performance is considered or high environmental resistance is needed, particularly when efficient manufacturing processes are used.

Pultrusion is one of the most efficient mass manufacturing processes of FRP composite structural shapes. Pultrusion is a continuous manufacturing process where fiber rovings, mats, and/or fabrics are impregnated with resin before being pulled through a heated die. Pultrusion is the ideal method for producing constant cross-section FRP structures of any length. A ‘load and resistance factor design’ (LRFD) standard for pultruded FRP structures has recently been produced and is currently in the ‘pre-standard’ stage of publication. In addition to its extensive coverage of design requirements, connections, and different loading condition, this pre-standard also briefly discusses the fatigue behavior of composite structures and proposes a design equation. As fatigue behavior is generally considered to be one of FRP’s advantages when compared to conventional construction materials, the efficiency of this equation is crucial for any applications where the structure will be subjected to cyclic loading (windmill blades, flexible structures in high-wind areas, ocean tides and waves, bridge structures, etc.).

sec.title: Pre-standard development
sec.p: The pre-standard has been under development for three years.1 The standard must still complete an ANSI standards process by the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) before it is adopted as the national standard.

The objective behind the development of the pre-standard is to allow FRP composites to compete with conventional construction materials by making their design and implementation more accessible and systematic. The pre-standard includes chapters on the design of members in tension, compression, flexure and shear as well as general design requirements, design of members under combined forces and torsion, design of plates and built-up members, and design of bolted connections.2

In the section on general design requirements of the pre-standard, equation (1) is proposed as the design guideline for fatigue, where C and m are empirical constants, Nf is the number of cycles to failure, and ΔS is the normalized stress range limit, or (σmax − σmin)/σult. The pre-standard specifies m as having a value of 8.5 while the value of C ranges from 0.01 to 10.0 depending on structural details (10.0 for plain material away from re-entrant corners or fasteners). While the basic structure of the formula is the Basquin S-N equation, it is not clearly explained in either the code or the commentary where the author obtained the values for m and C, other than the inclusion of a statement that they were determined from a regression analysis of fatigue tests. (1)(ΔS)limit=(C/Nf)1/m

sec.title: Fatigue life prediction
sec.p: Fatigue life prediction in composites is particularly complex due to the inhomogeneity and anisotropy of the material. Fiber type, matrix type, reinforcement structure, stacking sequence, manufacturing quality, loading conditions, environmental conditions, boundary conditions, and long-term behavior can all significantly affect fatigue behavior.3 In unidirectional composites, the fibers carry virtually the entire load; one would expect that the fatigue behavior would depend solely on the fibers, which have good resistance to fatigue. However, experimental results have shown that the fatigue behavior is determined principally by the strain in the matrix.4 When the weakest location in a composite fails, the surrounding fiber–matrix interface experiences increased local stresses, which can lead to eventual fatigue damage. The weakest location is, more often than not, caused by material defects, such as misaligned fibers, voids, resin-rich regions, or simply fibers with strengths located at the lower end of the statistical distribution present in all fibers. Because of all of these additional considerations, the fatigue behavior of composites is generally quite different from the behavior of isotropic materials, particularly metals, and different life prediction methods are needed.

In order to predict the fatigue behavior of a material, the remaining strength or the remaining number of cycles, the material properties, and the environmental/loading conditions must be related to the damage modes that the material is likely to experience. The fatigue behavior of resin–matrix composites depends on the interlaminar and intralaminar shear resistance, which in turn depends on the lamina properties, laminate stacking sequence, the environmental conditions (moisture, temperature), the testing frequency, and the stress ratios (min/max and max/ultimate).5 There have been numerous fatigue life prediction models for composite materials published in the past several years,3,6–16 with over 50 mentioned in a paper by Degrieck and Van Paepegem alone. These models are all generally based on empirical theories, theories based on strength or stiffness degradation, or progressive damage accumulation models. Many models have been established with regards to a particular material or manufacturing process, making the challenge the extrapolation of these models to real structures with different stacking sequences and complex loads.

sec.title: Strain energy-based fatigue life prediction equation
sec.p: One model that has been shown to match and predict the fatigue behavior of a number of different materials and layups is a strain-energy based model developed and implemented at the Constructed Facilities Center at West Virginia University (WVU-CFC).17 The WVU-CFC model takes into account the similar patterns of strain energy release rate observed among different glass-fiber reinforced composites along with the initial strain energy of the unstressed sample to predict the number of constant amplitude fatigue cycles to failure for a particular coupon or component. The model, shown in equation (2), relies on two constants, a and b, that can be either determined experimentally or approximated with reasonable accuracy based on similar experimental data. Additionally, in equation (2) Nf is 90% of the number of cycles to failure, Uo is the initial strain energy, and (σmax/σult) is the normalized maximum stress. (2)Nf=Uo2a(σmaxσult)b

sec.title: Equation development
sec.p: Both the pre-standard’s equation (1) and the WVU-CFC’s equation (2) are similar in format and based on the S-N relationship. While the normalized stress range used in equation (1) is the ratio of the stress range to the ultimate stress, the stress range in equation (2) is the ratio of the maximum stress to the ultimate stress (ΔS = σmax/σult). For small values of σmin, the two stress ranges are approximately equal. Throughout the rest of the derivations the max stress ratio is represented as ΔS unless otherwise noted. The equations can also be correlated with Nf, equation (1) ≈ Nf,equation (2), m = b, and C = Uo/2a.

In bending (simply supported, with the load concentrated at the center), the initial strain energy can be calculated as shown in equation (3), where σave is the average fatigue stress, I is moment of inertia of the section, L is the span length, c is the distance to the neutral axis, and E is the modulus of elasticity. (3)Uo=(σave)2/L6C2E

Once the average stress is converted to include a normalized stress range term, as shown in equation (4), the constant C can be rewritten as shown in equation (5), which is then related to the material properties, the stress range to be applied, and the WVU-CFC fatigue constant a. With these manipulations, the adjusted pre-standard equation could be written as equation (6), or rearranged for easier prediction of the number of cycles to failure as shown in equation (7). (4)σave=σmax-σmin2=ΔS*σult2 (5)C=(ΔS)2((σult)2IL48C2Ea) (6)ΔS=((σult)2IL48c2EaNf)1b-2 (7)Nf=1(ΔS)b-2((σult)2IL48c2Ea)

sec.title: Comparison with experimental data
sec.p:
Because of the difficulty associated with full-scale component fatigue testing, data from only a few (12) samples was available to apply these models.18 Two pultruded, glass-fiber beams were fatigue tested in flexure to failure (6 samples of each, with every sample at a different load level). One set of samples was a wide-flange (WF) beam shape while the other was a box beam shape (Figure 1). Both had cross-sections of 102 mm × 102 mm × 6 mm with a bending span of 1830 mm. Using the ASCE FRP Pre-Standard model and constants (m = 8.5, C = 10), for a given number of cycles, both beams are conservatively predicted to be able to withstand a stress ratio of about 60–70% that observed in experimentation (shown in Tables 1 and 2). Note that, since the beams were tested at a stress ratio of R = 0.1 (σmin/σmax = 0.1), the pre-standard stress ratio had to be divided by 0.9 to provide an accurate comparison. Figure 1.
Example of FRP structural shape in 3-point bending.
FRP: fiber-reinforced polymer.
Figure 2.
Comparison between pre-standard model and proposed modification.
Table 1.
Box beam life prediction with pre-standard equation and constants
A Number of cycles to failure 85000 10,0000 15,0000 20,0000 48,0000 73,5000
B Experimental stress ratio 0.56 0.54 0.51 0.50 0.48 0.45
C Pre-standard stress ratio 0.38 0.38 0.36 0.35 0.31 0.30
D C/B 68% 70% 70% 69% 65% 66%
Table 2.
Wide-flange beam life prediction with pre-standard equation and constants
A Number of cycles to failure 60000 75000 10,0000 16,0000 35,0000 65,0000
B Experimental stress ratio 0.68 0.65 0.62 0.59 0.55 0.53
C Pre-standard stress ratio 0.40 0.39 0.38 0.36 0.32 0.30
D C/B 59% 60% 61% 60% 59% 57%

From fatigue testing of the pultruded FRP samples, it was found that the b value (from the WVU-CFC model) for each of the beams was around 12, resulting in m¯ = b − 2 = 10, an adjusted m constant to simplify comparisons. When the adjusted m¯ is used, then an adjusted C¯ (independent of the stress range) must also be used, as shown in equation (8). The a value (which carries the unit of ‘N-mm’) for the box beam was approximately 720 and for the I-beam was approximately 100. Using the σult, I, L, c, and E material properties for these beams, the values shown in Table 3 were obtained as appropriately adjusted pre-standard constants. Although these constants produce significantly higher stress ranges than the suggested pre-standard constants, when compared to experimental values these prediction constants still seem to give adequately conservative estimates, as will be shown in the case study. (8)C¯=((σult)2IL48c2Ea) Table 3.
Adjusted pre-standard constants
m¯ C¯
Box beam 10 90
Wide-flange beam 10 460

While the above adjusted values seem to work reasonably well for the two types of FRP beams tested under fatigue, there is not enough component data available to get a good estimation of what kind of error there might be associated with these approximations. However, there is a large amount of coupon data available from a number of fatigue tests performed on pultruded FRP composites.

The accuracy of the WVU-CFC model was checked by applying the model to a large amount of glass FRP coupon fatigue data, some of which was generated by the WVU-CFC but the majority of which was generated by Montana State University in their creation of an FRP fatigue database.19 The model was found to be able to fit 80–90% of over 1200 fatigue tests to within ±5% logarithmic error on their respective S-N curves and to predict fatigue life of glass-polyester FRP coupons to within ±5% logarithmic error using only two empirical data points with 75% success – more empirical data further improved the accuracy.17 The model was able to, on average, predict the number of cycles to failure to within 3.6% on the logarithmic scale with a standard deviation of 3.0% on the logarithmic scale, which is reasonable accuracy for conservative fatigue life prediction. The identical procedure performed on the FRP Box and WF beams resulted in predictions within ±2.5% log error, indicating a potential for even better accuracy when applied to full-size FRP components.

From looking at the coupon test results (75 total samples of 7 FRP pultruded glass-polyester material combinations), the b constant varies from about 11 to 16 while the a constant varies from approximately 113 to 11,300 (N-mm). If b is assumed to remain approximately 12 for FRP components and a is varied across the range seen in the pultruded coupons, Table 4 is populated, where R is the average value of (experimental ΔS)/(calculated ΔS) for each set of constants. Table 4.
Influence of a factor on ΔS ratio (m¯ = 10)
b a m¯ C¯ R
Box beam 12 113 10 550 0.91
12 565 10 110 1.07
12 1469 10 40 1.18
12 3390 10 18 1.29
12 11,300 10 5.5 1.45
Wide-flange beam 12 113 10 460 1.07
12 565 10 90 1.27
12 1469 10 35 1.38
12 3390 10 15 1.50
12 11,300 10 4.6 1.70

Assuming the factor of safety to be applied should be three standard deviations, the number of cycles to failure for each stress level should be modified by 3 × 3.0% = 9.0% on the logarithmic scale. It has previously been shown that over 97% of coupons are within 10% of the logarithmic error using this fatigue model.17 After applying the safety factor modification to the experimental results for number of cycles to failure, it was found that the stress level should be increased by a factor between a maximum of 1.18 for a normalized fatigue stress of 0.2 and a minimum of 1.05 for a normalized fatigue stress of 0.8. Taking the value of 1.18 to be the most conservative, it can be seen in Table 4 that, if m¯ has a value of 10, a should have a value of around 1469 N-mm to provide the minimum appropriate margin of three standard deviations for both shapes. With these modifications incorporated (along with ΔS as the maximum stress ratio instead of the normalize stress range), the pre-standard equation would include the material properties of the sections to be fatigued in flexure as shown in equation (9). For undamaged FRP components, without joints, it is therefore recommended that m¯ should have a value of 10 and a should have a value of 1469 N-mm in equation (9) to provide the appropriate three standard deviation factor of safety. (9)ΔS=((σult)2IL48c2EaNf)1m¯

sec.title: Case study
sec.p:
For the box beam described previously (with the properties given in Table 5), what normalized stress range should be selected to allow for 100,000 cycles of bending fatigue? Table 5.
Case study box beam properties
σult 177.2 MPa
L 1830 mm
E 23.5 GPa
I 3.14 × 106 mm4
c 51 mm
A: Using the current ASCE FRP pre-standard fatigue prediction equation (with m = 8.5 and C = 10), the recommended normalized stress range, ΔS, is (10)ΔS=(10100,000)18.5=0.34
B: Using the proposed modifications (with m¯ = 10 and a = 1469), the recommended normalized stress range, ΔS, is (11)ΔS=((177.2)2*3.14*106*183048*512*(23.5*103)*1469*100,000)110=0.46

The experimentally determined normalized stress range that results in approximately 100,000 fatigue cycles to failure is 0.54. Fatiguing the box beam under a normalized stress range of 0.46 has been experimentally determined to last around 500,000 cycles, or 5 times longer than predicted using the modified pre-standard equation. Fatiguing the box beam under a normalized stress range of 0.34 (which is equivalent to a max stress ratio of 0.38 for σmin = 0.1*σmax) would last an estimated 5,000,000 cycles, or 50 times longer than predicted using the original pre-standard equation. Note that three standard deviations of the error in predicting the number of cycles to failure using the WVU-CFC fatigue model results would allow for a maximum of around 300,000 cycles, which is reasonably close to the prediction from case B. While the original pre-standard equation constants also likely contained some built-in factor of safety, it is not made clear what the reasoning was behind the choice of this factor and it appears to make the fatigue life prediction too conservative.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Both the current pre-standard fatigue equation and the one developed by WVU-CFC are based on an S-N relationship; the WVU-CFC equation also includes some material and geometric properties. When compared to experimental data, the pre-standard fatigue equation is shown to provide an overly conservative fatigue life prediction which may rule out pultruded FRP from consideration for infrastructure applications with cyclic loading. By incorporating the WVU-CFC fatigue model into the pre-standard model, the section properties are included in the calculation and the end result is significantly less conservative. In the example presented, the pre-standard equation under-calculated the fatigue strength ratio such that the lifetime of the component would be 50 times what was desired; in comparison, the modified equation under-calculated the fatigue strength ratio such that the lifetime of the component would be only 5 times what was desired. This proposed adjustment to the pre-standard fatigue model would provide more accurate, yet still conservative, life predictions which would qualify pultruded FRP composites to be used in a greater variety of cyclic loading applications.

Application of the modified fatigue equation to more and differing experimental results, including different section shapes and products from different manufacturers, would help provide better evidence for acceptance or rejection of the proposed changes. Additionally, fatigue data generated in tension, compression, torsion, or combined loading (with proper adjustment for initial strain energy, Uo) is needed in order to expand the application of the model to those loading conditions.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Funding for this work was provided through a Graduate Research Fellowship by the National Science Foundation.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
